Text 1: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. He was without sin and upright, fearing God and keeping himself far from evil.
Text 2: There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job. That man was blameless and upright, and one who feared God, and turned away from evil.

Text 1: And of cattle he had seven thousand sheep and goats, and three thousand camels, and a thousand oxen, and five hundred she-asses, and a very great number of servants. And the man was greater than any of the sons of the east.
Text 2:
His possessions also were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels,
five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very great household; so that this man was
the greatest of all the children of the east.

Text 1: His sons regularly went to one another's houses, and every one on his day gave a feast: and at these times they sent for their three sisters to take part in their feasts with them.
Text 2: And his sons went, and made a feast by houses every one in his day. And sending they called their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

Text 1: His sons regularly went to one another's houses, and every one on his day gave a feast: and at these times they sent for their three sisters to take part in their feasts with them.
Text 2: And his sons went and made a feast in the house of each one on his day; and they sent and invited their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.

Text 1: And his sons went and held a feast in the house of each one upon his day; and they sent and called for their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
Text 2:
His sons went and held a feast in the house of each one on his birthday;
and they sent and called for their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.

Text 1: And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt-offerings according to the number of them all: for Job said, It may be that my sons have sinned, and renounced God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.
Text 2: And it was so, when the days of the feasting were gone about, that Job sent and hallowed them; and he rose up early in the morning, and offered up burnt-offerings [according to] the number of them all; for Job said, It may be that my children have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.

Text 1: And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt-offerings according to the number of them all: for Job said, It may be that my sons have sinned, and renounced God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.
Text 2: And when the days of their feasting were gone about, Job sent to them, and sanctified them: and rising up early offered holocausts for every one of them. For he said: Lest perhaps my sons have sinned, and have blessed God in their hearts. So did Job all days.

Text 1: And at the end of their days of feasting, Job sent and made them clean, getting up early in the morning and offering burned offerings for them all. For, Job said, It may be that my sons have done wrong and said evil of God in their hearts. And Job did this whenever the feasts came round.

Thus did Job continually.

Thus did Job continually.

Text 1: Then the Lord said to Satan: Behold, all that he hath is in thy hand: only put not forth thy hand upon his person. And Satan went forth from the presence of the Lord.
Text 2:
Yahweh said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your power. Only on himself don’t stretch out your hand.”
So Satan went out from the presence of Yahweh.

Text 2: and behold, there came a great wind from the wilderness, and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young men, and they are dead. I alone have escaped to tell you.”

Text 1: And the Lord said to the Satan, Where do you come from? And the Satan said in answer, From wandering this way and that on the earth, and walking about on it.
Text 2: That the Lord said to Satan: Whence comest thou ? And he answered and said: I have gone round about the earth, and walked through it.

Text 1: And the Lord said to the Satan, Where do you come from? And the Satan said in answer, From wandering this way and that on the earth, and walking about on it.
Text 2: And the LORD said unto Satan, From whence comest thou? And Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.

Text 1: And Jehovah said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job? for there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and turneth away from evil: and he still holdeth fast his integrity, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause.
Text 2:
The LORD said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? For
there is no one like him in the earth, a blameless and an upright man, one who fears God, and turns away
from evil. He still maintains his integrity, although you incited me against him, to ruin him without
cause.”

Text 1: And Jehovah said to Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God and abstaineth from evil? and still he remaineth firm in his integrity, though thou movedst me against him, to swallow him up without cause.
Text 2: And the Lord said to Satan: Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a man simple, and upright, and fearing Cod, and avoiding evil, and still keeping his innocence ? But thou hast moved me against him, that I sho uld afflict him without cause.

Text 1: And he said to her: Thou hast; spoken like one of the foolish women: if we have received good things at the hand of God, why should we not receive evil? In all these things Job did not sin with his lips.
Text 2:
But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women would
speak. What? Shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil?”
In all this Job didn’t sin with his lips.

Text 1: And he said to her, You are talking like one of the foolish women. If we take the good God sends us, are we not to take the evil when it comes? In all this Job kept his lips from sin.

Text 1: Now when Job's three friends heard all the evil that had befallen him, they came every one from his own place, Alphas the Themanite, and Baldad the Suhite, and Sophar the Naamathite. For they had made an appointment to come together and visit him, a nd comfort him.

Now when Job`s three friends heard of all this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place: Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, and they made an appointment together to come to bemoan him and to comfort him.
Text 2: And Job's three friends had word of all this evil which had come on him. And they came every one from his place, Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. So they came together to a meeting-place, in order that they might go and make clear to Job their grief for him, and give him comfort.

Text 2: And three friends of Job heard of all this evil that was come upon him. And they came each one from his place: Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite; and they made an appointment together to come to condole with him and to comfort him.

So they came together to a meeting-place, in order that they might go and make clear to Job their grief for him, and give him comfort.
Text 2: Now when Job's three friends heard all the evil that had befallen him, they came every one from his own place, Alphas the Themanite, and Baldad the Suhite, and Sophar the Naamathite. For they had made an appointment to come together and visit him, a nd comfort him.

Text 1: And when they lifted up their eyes afar off, and knew him not, they lifted up their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his robe, and sprinkled dust upon their heads toward heaven.
Text 2: And lifting up their eyes when they were still far off, it did not seem that the man they saw was Job because of the change in him. And they gave way to bitter weeping, with signs of grief, and put dust on their heads.

Text 1: That day--let it be dark; let not God take note of it from on high, and let not the light be shining on it;
Text 2:

Text 1: From morning till evening they shall be cut down: and because no one understandeth, they shall perish for ever.
Text 2:

Between morning and evening they are destroyed.
They perish forever without any regarding it.

Text 1: Betwixt morning and evening they are destroyed: They perish for ever without any regarding it.
Text 2: From morning till evening they shall be cut down: and because no one understandeth, they shall perish for ever.

Text 1: Is not their tent-cord plucked up within them? They die, and that without wisdom.
Text 2: If their tent-cord is pulled up, do they not come to an end, and without wisdom?

Text 1: Is not their tent-cord torn away in them? they die, and without wisdom.
Text 2:
Doth not their excellency
which is in them go away? they die, even without wisdom.

Doth not their excellency
which is in them go away? they die, even without wisdom.

Text 1: Although affliction cometh not forth of the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground;

neither does trouble spring out of the ground;

They are as loathsome food to me.

Text 2:
The things
that my soul refused to touch
are as my sorrowful meat.

Text 1: To him that is ready to faint kindness [should be showed]       from his friend; Even to him that forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.

should be shewed from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.

“To him who is ready to faint, kindness should be shown from his friend;
even to him who forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
To him that is ready to faint kindness [should be showed]       from his friend; Even to him that forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
Text 2: He that taketh away mercy from his friend, forsaketh the fear of the Lord.

Text 1: To him that is ready to faint kindness [should be showed]       from his friend; Even to him that forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
Text 2: He whose heart is shut against his friend has given up the fear of the Ruler of all.

Text 1: To him that is ready to faint kindness [should be showed]       from his friend; Even to him that forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
Text 2: For him that is fainting kindness [is meet] from his friend; or he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.

Text 1: Return, I pray you, let there be no wrong; yea, return again, my righteousness shall be in it.
Text 2:
Return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yea, return again, my righteousness
is in it.

Text 1: Let your minds be changed, and do not have an evil opinion of me; yes, be changed, for my righteousness is still in me.
Text 2:
Please return.
Let there be no injustice.
Yes, return again.
My cause is righteous.

Text 1: Is there not a warfare to man upon earth? And are not his days like the days of a hireling?
Text 2: Has not man his ordered time of trouble on the earth? and are not his days like the days of a servant working for payment?

Text 1: When I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone? and I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
Text 2:
When I lie down, I say,
‘When will I arise, and the night be gone?’
I toss and turn until the dawning of the day.

Text 1: When I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone? And I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
Text 2: When I go to my bed, I say, When will it be time to get up? but the night is long, and I am turning from side to side till morning light.

Text 1: When I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone? And I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
Text 2: If I lie down, I say, When shall I rise up, and the darkness be gone? and I am full of tossings until the dawn.

Text 2: If I lie down to sleep, I shall say: When shall arise? and again I shall look for the evening, and shall be filled with sorrows even till darkness.

My skin closes up, and breaks out afresh.

Text 1: If I have sinned, what do I unto thee, O thou watcher of       men? Why hast thou set me as a mark for thee, So that I am a burden to myself?
Text 2: I have sinned: what shall I do to thee, O keeper of men? why hast thou set me opposite to thee, and I am become burdensome to myself?

Text 1: Why dost thou not remove my sin, and why dost thou not take away my iniquity? Behold now I shall sleep in the dust: and if thou seek me in the morning, I shall not be.
Text 2:
Why do you not pardon my disobedience, and take away my iniquity?
For now will I lie down in the dust.
You will seek me diligently, but I will not be.”

Text 1: If he puts out his hand to take, by whom may it be turned back? who may say to him, What are you doing?
Text 2:

Who can hinder him?

Text 1: If [we speak] of strength, lo, [he is] mighty! And if of justice, Who, [saith he], will summon me?
Text 2: If it is a question of strength, he says, Here I am! and if it is a question of a cause at law, he says, Who will give me a fixed day?

Text 1: If [we speak] of strength, lo, [he is] mighty! And if of justice, Who, [saith he], will summon me?
Text 2:
If
I speak of strength, lo,
he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time
to plead?

Text 1: If [we speak] of strength, lo, [he is] mighty! And if of justice, Who, [saith he], will summon me?
Text 2: If strength be demanded, he is most strong: if equity of judgment, no man dare bear witness for me.

Text 1: If it is a question of strength, he says, Here I am! and if it is a question of a cause at law, he says, Who will give me a fixed day?

If it is a matter of strength, behold, he is mighty!
If of justice, ‘Who,’ says he, ‘will summon me?’

he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time
to plead?

Text 1:
If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me:
if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
Text 2:
Though I am righteous, my own mouth will condemn me.
Though I am blameless, it will prove me perverse.

Text 1:
Though I
were perfect,
yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.
Text 2:
I am blameless.
I don’t respect myself.
I despise my life.

Text 2: I have done no wrong; I give no thought to what becomes of me; I have no desire for life.

Text 1:
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked.
He covers the faces of its judges.
If not he, then who is it?
Text 2:
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked.
He covers the faces of its judges.
If not he, then who is it?

I am to be one that is a derision to his friend, I who call upon God, and whom he will answer: a derision is the just upright [man].
Text 2: He that is mocked by his friends as I, shall call upon God and he will hear him: for the simplicity of the just man is laughed to scorn.

Text 1:
I am
as one mocked of his neighbour, who calleth upon God, and he answereth him: the just upright
man is laughed to scorn.
Text 2:
I am like one who is a joke to his neighbour,
I, who called on God, and he answered.
The just, the blameless man is a joke.

Text 1: He that is ready to stumble with the foot is a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
Text 2: The lamp despised in the thoughts of the rich, is ready for the time appointed.

Text 1: The lamp despised in the thoughts of the rich, is ready for the time appointed.
Text 2:
In the thought of him who is at ease there is contempt for misfortune.
It is ready for them whose foot slips.

Text 1: In the thought of him who is in comfort there is no respect for one who is in trouble; such is the fate of those whose feet are slipping.
Text 2:
In the thought of him who is at ease there is contempt for misfortune.
It is ready for them whose foot slips.

Text 1:
He that is ready to slip with
his feet
is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
Text 2:
In the thought of him who is at ease there is contempt for misfortune.
It is ready for them whose foot slips.

Text 1: In the thought of him that is at ease there is contempt       for misfortune; It is ready for them whose foot slippeth.
Text 2: He that is ready to stumble with the foot is a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.

Text 1: The tabernacles of robbers abound, and they provoke God boldly; whereas it is he that hath given all into their hands:
Text 2:
The tents of robbers prosper.
Those who provoke God are secure,
who carry their god in their hands.

Text 1: The tents of robbers prosper, And they that provoke God are secure; Into whose hand God bringeth [abundantly].
Text 2: There is wealth in the tents of those who make destruction, and those by whom God is moved to wrath are safe; even those whose god is their strength.

Text 1: The tents of robbers prosper, And they that provoke God are secure; Into whose hand God bringeth [abundantly].
Text 2: The tents of desolators are in peace, and they that provoke God are secure; into whose hand God bringeth.

and takes away the understanding of the elders.

Text 1: Is it good unto thee that thou shouldest oppress, That thou shouldest despise the work of thy hands, And shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
Text 2: What profit is it to you to be cruel, to give up the work of your hands, looking kindly on the design of evil-doers?

Text 1: But vain man is void of understanding, Yea, man is born [as] a wild ass`s colt.
Text 2: And so a hollow-minded man will get wisdom, when a young ass of the field gets teaching.

Text 1: But vain man is void of understanding, Yea, man is born [as] a wild ass`s colt.
Text 2: Yet a senseless man will make bold, though man be born [like] the foal of a wild ass.

Text 1: But vain man is void of understanding, Yea, man is born [as] a wild ass`s colt.
Text 2: A vain man is lifted up into pride, and thinketh himself born free like a wild ass's colt.

Text 1: But vain man is void of understanding, Yea, man is born [as] a wild ass`s colt.
Text 2:
For vain man would be wise, though man be born
like a wild ass’s colt.

when a man is born as a wild donkey’s colt.

An empty-headed man becomes wise
when a man is born as a wild donkey’s colt.

Text 1:

like a wild ass’s colt.
Text 2:
An empty-headed man becomes wise
when a man is born as a wild donkey’s colt.

Text 1: And if [my head] exalt itself, thou huntest me as a lion; And again thou showest thyself marvellous upon me.

Text 1: Should thy boastings make men hold their peace? And when thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed?
Text 2: Are your words of pride to make men keep quiet? and are you to make sport, with no one to put you to shame?

Text 2: Should thy fictions make men hold their peace? and shouldest thou mock, and no one make [thee] ashamed?

Text 1: If I be wicked, woe unto me; And if I be righteous, yet shall I not lift up my head; Being filled with ignominy, And looking upon mine affliction.
Text 2: That, if I was an evil-doer, the curse would come on me; and if I was upright, my head would not be lifted up, being full of shame and overcome with trouble.

Text 1: Thou renewest thy witnesses against me, And increasest thine indignation upon me: Changes and warfare are with me.

Text 1: And [thy] life shall be clearer than the noonday;  Though there be darkness, it shall be as the morning.
Text 2: And your life will be brighter than day; though it is dark, it will become like the morning.

Text 1: For he knoweth false men: He seeth iniquity also, even though he consider it not.
Text 2: For in his eyes men are as nothing; he sees evil and takes note of it.

Text 1: And that he would show thee the secrets of wisdom! For he is manifold in understanding. Know therefore that God exacteth of thee less than thine       iniquity deserveth.
Text 2: And would make clear to you the secrets of wisdom, and the wonders of his purpose!

Text 1: And that he would show thee the secrets of wisdom! For he is manifold in understanding. Know therefore that God exacteth of thee less than thine       iniquity deserveth.
Text 2: And that he would shew thee the secrets of wisdom, how that they are the double of what is realised; and know that God passeth by [much] of thine iniquity!

Text 1: Thy hands have framed me and fashioned me Together round about; yet thou dost destroy me.
Text 2: Your hands made me, and I was formed by you, but then, changing your purpose, you gave me up to destruction.

Text 1: Thy hands have framed me and fashioned me Together round about; yet thou dost destroy me.
Text 2: Thy hands have bound me together and made me as one, round about; yet dost thou swallow me up!

Text 1: Thy hands have framed me and fashioned me Together round about; yet thou dost destroy me.
Text 2: Thy hands have made me, and fashioned me wholly round about, and dost thou thus cast me down headlong on a sudden?

Text 2: Thine hands have made me and fashioned me together round about; yet thou dost destroy me.

yet you destroy me.

Text 1: Canst thou by searching find out God? Canst thou find out the Almighty unto perfection?
Text 2: Are you able to take God's measure, to make discovery of the limits of the Ruler of all?

Text 2: Canst thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the Almighty to perfection?

Text 2: Peradventure thou wilt comprehend the steps of God, and wilt find out the Almighty perfectly?

Or can you probe the limits of the Almighty?

Text 1: And thou shalt be secure, because there is hope; Yea, thou shalt search [about thee], and shalt take thy rest in       safety.

Text 1: Wherefore then hast thou brought me forth out of the       womb? I had given up the ghost, and no eye had seen me.

Text 1: If he pass through, and shut up, And all unto judgment, then who can hinder him?
Text 2: If he goes on his way, shutting a man up and putting him to death, who may make him go back from his purpose?

Text 1: Who is he that will contend with me? For then would I hold my peace and give up the ghost.
Text 2: Is any one able to take up the argument against me? If so, I would keep quiet and give up my breath.

Text 1: Behold, he will slay me; I have no hope: Nevertheless I will maintain my ways before him.
Text 2: Truly, he will put an end to me; I have no hope; but I will not give way in argument before him;

Text 2: Behold, if he slay me, yet would I trust in him; but I will defend mine own ways before him.

Text 1: Wilt thou harass a driven leaf? And wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
Text 2: Will you be hard on a leaf in flight before the wind? will you make a dry stem go more quickly on its way?

Text 2: Wilt thou terrify a driven leaf? and wilt thou pursue dry stubble?

Text 2: Against a leaf, that is carried away with the wind, thou shewest thy power, and thou pursuest a dry straw.

You also put my feet in the stocks,
and mark all my paths.
You set a bound to the soles of my feet,

Text 1: Surely I would speak to the Almighty, And I desire to reason with God.
Text 2: But I would have talk with the Ruler of all, and my desire is to have an argument with God.

Text 1: Though I am like a rotten thing that consumeth, Like a garment that is moth-eaten.
Text 2: Though a man comes to nothing like a bit of dead wood, or like a robe which has become food for the worm.

Text 2: One who, as a rotten thing consumeth, as a garment that the moth eateth.

Text 1: Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, Your defences are defences of clay.
Text 2: Your wise sayings are only dust, and your strong places are only earth.

Text 1: Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, Your defences are defences of clay.
Text 2: Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, your bulwarks are bulwarks of mire.

Text 1: But ye are forgers of lies; Ye are all physicians of no value.
Text 2: But you put a false face on things; all your attempts to put things right are of no value.

Text 2: For ye indeed are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.

Text 1: The waters wear the stones; The overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth: So thou destroyest the hope of man.
Text 2: The stones are crushed small by the force of the waters; the dust of the earth is washed away by their overflowing: and so you put an end to the hope of man.

Text 1: The waters wear the stones; The overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth: So thou destroyest the hope of man.
Text 2: The waters wear the stones, the floods thereof wash away the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man.

Text 1: The waters wear the stones; The overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth: So thou destroyest the hope of man.
Text 2: Waters wear away the stones, and with inundation the ground by little and little is washed away: so in like manner thou shalt destroy man.

Text 1: The waters wear the stones; The overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth: So thou destroyest the hope of man.

out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man.

out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man.

Text 1: But man dieth, and is laid low: Yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he?
Text 2: But man comes to his death and is gone: he gives up his spirit, and where is he?

Text 1: Oh that thou wouldest hide me in Sheol, That thou wouldest keep me secret, until thy wrath be past, That thou wouldest appoint me a set time, and remember me!

Text 1: So man lieth down and riseth not: Till the heavens be no more, they shall not awake, Nor be roused out of their sleep.

Text 1: Look away from him, that he may rest, Till he shall accomplish, as a hireling, his day.

Text 1: Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth; Thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away.
Text 2: You overcome him for ever, and he is gone; his face is changed in death, and you send him away.

Text 1: If a man die, shall he live [again]? All the days of my warfare would I wait, Till my release should come.
Text 2: If death takes a man, will he come to life again? All the days of my trouble I would be waiting, till the time came for me to be free.

Text 1: Yea, thou doest away with fear, And hinderest devotion before God.
Text 2: Truly, you make the fear of God without effect, so that the time of quiet worship before God is made less by your outcry.

Text 2: Yea, thou makest piety of none effect, and restrainest meditation before God.

Text 1: He shall shake off his unripe grape as the vine, And shall cast off his flower as the olive-tree.
Text 2: He is like a vine whose grapes do not come to full growth, or an olive-tree dropping its flowers.

Text 1: The wicked man travaileth with pain all his days, Even the number of years that are laid up for the oppressor.
Text 2: The evil man is in pain all his days, and the number of the years stored up for the cruel is small.

Text 2: All his days the wicked man is tormented, and numbered years are allotted to the violent.

Text 1: He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance       continue, Neither shall their possessions be extended on the earth.

Text 1: For the company of the godless shall be barren, And fire shall consume the tents of bribery.
Text 2: For the band of the evil-doers gives no fruit, and the tents of those who give wrong decisions for reward are burned with fire.

Text 1: Let him not trust in vanity, deceiving himself; For vanity shall be his recompense.
Text 2: Let him not put his hope in what is false, falling into error: for he will get deceit as his reward.

Text 2: Let him not trust in vanity: he is deceived, for vanity shall be his recompense;

Text 2: He shall not believe, being vainly deceived by error, that he may be redeemed with any price.

Text 2: Let not him that is deceived trust in vanity: for vanity shall be his recompence.

He knows that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.

Text 1: And thou hast laid fast hold on me, [which] is a witness       [against me]: And my leanness riseth up against me, It testifieth to my face.
Text 2: It has come up as a witness against me, and the wasting of my flesh makes answer to my face.

Text 2: But now he has overcome me with weariness and fear, and I am in the grip of all my trouble.

Text 1: His archers compass me round about; He cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; He poureth out my gall upon the ground.
Text 2: His bowmen come round about me; their arrows go through my body without mercy; my life is drained out on the earth.

Text 1: His archers compass me round about; He cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; He poureth out my gall upon the ground.

Text 1: Though I speak, my grief is not assuaged; And though I forbear, what am I eased?
Text 2: If I say what is in my mind, my pain becomes no less: and if I keep quiet, how much of it goes from me?

Text 2: I would strengthen you with my mouth, and would move my lips, as sparing you.

Text 1: O earth, cover not thou my blood, And let my cry have no [resting] -place.
Text 2: O earth, let not my blood be covered, and let my cry have no resting-place!

Text 2: O earth, cover not my blood, and let there be no place for my cry!

Text 2: These things have I suffered without the iniquity of my hand, when I offered pure prayers to God.

Text 1: I was at ease, and he brake me asunder; Yea, he hath taken me by the neck, and dashed me to pieces: He hath also set me up for his mark.
Text 2: I was in comfort, but I have been broken up by his hands; he has taken me by the neck, shaking me to bits; he has put me up as a mark for his arrows.

Text 1: For when a few years are come, I shall go the way whence I shall not return.
Text 2: For in a short time I will take the journey from which I will not come back.

Text 1: That he would maintain the right of a man with God, And of a son of man with his neighbor!
Text 2: So that he may give decision for a man in his cause with God, and between a son of man and his neighbour.

Text 1: But as for you all, come on now again; And I shall not find a wise man among you.
Text 2: But come back, now, all of you, come; and I will not see a wise man among you.

Text 1: They change the night into day: The light, [say they], is near unto the darkness.

Text 1: Give now a pledge, be surety for me with thyself; Who is there that will strike hands with me?
Text 2: Be pleased, now, to be responsible for me to yourself; for there is no other who will put his hand in mine.

is he
that will strike hands with me?

Text 1: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, Even the thoughts of my heart.
Text 2: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, even the desires of my heart.

Text 1: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, Even the thoughts of my heart.
Text 2: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, the cherished thoughts of my heart.

Text 1: He that denounceth his friends for a prey, Even the eyes of his children shall fail.

Text 1: Surely there are mockers with me, And mine eye dwelleth upon their provocation.

Text 1: It shall go down to the bars of Sheol, When once there is rest in the dust.

Text 2: My spirit is broken, my days are ended, the last resting-place is ready for me.

Text 2: How long will it be before you have done talking? Get wisdom, and then we will say what is in our minds.

Text 1: My breath is strange to my wife, And my supplication to the children of mine own mother.
Text 2: My breath is strange to my wife, and I am disgusting to the offspring of my mother's body.

Text 1: They that dwell in my house, and my maids, count me for       a stranger; I am an alien in their sight.
Text 2: I am strange to my women-servants, and seem to them as one from another country.

Text 1: Behold, I cry out of wrong, but I am not heard: I cry for help, but there is no justice.
Text 2: Truly, I make an outcry against the violent man, but there is no answer: I give a cry for help, but no one takes up my cause.

Text 1: There was nothing left that he devoured not; Therefore his prosperity shall not endure.
Text 2: He had never enough for his desire; for this cause his well-being will quickly come to an end.

Text 1: I have heard the reproof which putteth me to shame; And the spirit of my understanding answereth me.
Text 2: I have to give ear to arguments which put me to shame, and your answers to me are wind without wisdom.

Text 1: He draweth it forth, and it cometh out of his body; Yea, the glittering point cometh out of his gall: Terrors are upon him.

Text 2: The sword is drawn out, and cometh forth from its scabbard, and glittereth in his bitterness: the terrible ones shall go and come upon him.

Text 1: In the fulness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits: The hand of every one that is in misery shall come upon him.
Text 2: Even when his wealth is great, he is full of care, for the hand of everyone who is in trouble is turned against him.

Text 1: All darkness is laid up for his treasures: A fire not blown [by man] shall devour him; It shall consume that which is left in his tent.
Text 2: All his wealth is stored up for the dark: a fire not made by man sends destruction on him, and on everything in his tent.

Text 1: All darkness is laid up for his treasures: A fire not blown [by man] shall devour him; It shall consume that which is left in his tent.
Text 2: All darkness is laid up for his treasures: a fire not blown shall devour him; it shall feed upon what is left in his tent.

Text 1: All darkness is laid up for his treasures: A fire not blown [by man] shall devour him; It shall consume that which is left in his tent.
Text 2: All darkness is hid in his secret places: a fire that is not kindled shall devour him, he shall be afflicted when left in his tabernacle.

Text 1: When he is about to fill his belly, [God] will cast the       fierceness of his wrath upon him, And will rain it upon him while he is eating.
Text 2: God gives him his desire, and sends the heat of his wrath on him, making it come down on him like rain.

Text 1: When he is about to fill his belly, [God] will cast the       fierceness of his wrath upon him, And will rain it upon him while he is eating.
Text 2: It shall be that, to fill his belly, he will cast his fierce anger upon him, and will rain it upon him into his flesh.

Text 1: Because he knew no quietness within him, He shall not save aught of that wherein he delighteth.
Text 2: There is no peace for him in his wealth, and no salvation for him in those things in which he took delight.

Text 1: Because he knew no quietness within him, He shall not save aught of that wherein he delighteth.
Text 2: Because he knew no rest in his craving, he shall save nought of what he most desired.

Text 1: Because he knew no quietness within him, He shall not save aught of that wherein he delighteth.
Text 2: And yet his belly was not filled: and when he hath the things he coveted, he shall not be able to possess them.

Text 1: Because he knew no quietness within him, He shall not save aught of that wherein he delighteth.
Text 2: Surely he shall not feel quietness in his belly, he shall not save of that which he desired.

he shall not save anything of that in which he delights.

“Because he knew no quietness within him,
he will not save anything of that in which he delights.

Text 1: [Ye say], God layeth up his iniquity for his children. Let him recompense it unto himself, that he may know it:
Text 2: You say, God keeps punishment stored up for his children. Let him send it on the man himself, so that he may have the punishment of it!

Text 1: How then comfort ye me in vain, Seeing in your answers there remaineth [only] falsehood?
Text 2: Why then do you give me comfort with words in which there is no profit, when you see that there is nothing in your answers but deceit?

Text 1: How then comfort ye me in vain, Seeing in your answers there remaineth [only] falsehood?
Text 2: How then comfort ye me in vain? Your answers remain perfidious.

Text 1: How then comfort ye me in vain, Seeing in your answers there remaineth [only] falsehood?
Text 2: How then do ye comfort me in vain, whereas your answer is shewn to be repugnant to truth ?

Text 1: How then comfort ye me in vain, Seeing in your answers there remaineth [only] falsehood?
Text 2: How then comfort ye me in vain, seeing in your answers there remaineth falsehood?

Text 2:
So how can you comfort me with nonsense,
because in your answers there remains only falsehood?”

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2: Is it possible for a man to be of profit to God? No, for a man's wisdom is only of profit to himself.

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2: Can a man be profitable to God? surely it is unto himself that the wise man is profitable.

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2: Can man be compared with God, even though he were of perfect knowledge?

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2: Can a man be profitable unto God, as he that is wise may be profitable unto himself?

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2:
“Can a man be profitable to God?
Surely he who is wise is profitable to himself.

Text 1: Can a man be profitable unto God? Surely he that is wise is profitable unto himself.
Text 2:
“Can a man be profitable to God?
Surely he who is wise is profitable to himself.

Text 1: Is it possible for a man to be of profit to God? No, for a man's wisdom is only of profit to himself.
Text 2: Can a man be profitable to God? surely it is unto himself that the wise man is profitable.

Text 2: Can man be compared with God, even though he were of perfect knowledge?

You have sent widows away empty,
and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.

Text 1: Is not God in the height of heaven? And behold the height of the stars, how high they are!
Text 2: Is not God as high as heaven? and see the stars, how high they are!

Text 1: Because I was not cut off before the darkness, Neither did he cover the thick darkness from my face.
Text 2: For I am overcome by the dark, and by the black night which is covering my face.

Text 1: Because I was not cut off before the darkness, Neither did he cover the thick darkness from my face.
Text 2: Because I was not cut off before the darkness, neither hath he hidden the gloom from me.

Text 1: Even to-day is my complaint rebellious: My stroke is heavier than my groaning.
Text 2: Even today my outcry is bitter; his hand is hard on my sorrow.

Text 2: Even to-day is my complaint bitter: my stroke is heavier than my groaning.

Text 2: Now also my words are in bitterness, and the hand of my scourge is more grievous than my mourning.

Text 2: If only I had knowledge of where he might be seen, so that I might come even to his seat!

Text 1: For he performeth that which is appointed for me: And many such things are with him.
Text 2: For what has been ordered for me by him will be gone through to the end: and his mind is full of such designs.

Text 1: On the left hand, when he doth work, but I cannot behold       him; He hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him.
Text 2: I am looking for him on the left hand, but there is no sign of him; and turning to the right, I am not able to see him.

Text 1: On the left hand, when he doth work, but I cannot behold       him; He hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him.
Text 2: On the left hand, where he doth work, but I behold [him] not; he hideth himself on the right hand, and I see [him] not.

Text 1: On the left hand, when he doth work, but I cannot behold       him; He hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him.
Text 2: If to the left hand, what shall I do? I shall not take hold on him: if I turn myself to the right hand, I shall not see him.

 he hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see

Text 1: I have not gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have treasured up the words of his mouth more than my       necessary food.
Text 2: I have never gone against the orders of his lips; the words of his mouth have been stored up in my heart.

Text 1: I have not gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have treasured up the words of his mouth more than my       necessary food.
Text 2: Neither have I gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have laid up the words of his mouth more than the purpose of my own heart.

Text 1: I have not gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have treasured up the words of his mouth more than my       necessary food.
Text 2: I have not departed from the commandments of his lips, and the words of his mouth I have hid in my bosom.

Text 1: But he is in one [mind], and who can turn him? And what his soul desireth, even that he doeth.
Text 2: But his purpose is fixed and there is no changing it; and he gives effect to the desire of his soul.

Text 1: They make oil within the walls of these men;  They tread [their] winepresses, and suffer thirst.

Text 1: From out of the populous city men groan,  And the soul of the wounded crieth out:  Yet God regardeth not the folly.
Text 2: From the town come sounds of pain from those who are near death, and the soul of the wounded is crying out for help; but God does not take note of their prayer.

Text 1: From out of the populous city men groan,  And the soul of the wounded crieth out:  Yet God regardeth not the folly.
Text 2: Men groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded crieth out; and God imputeth not the impiety.

Text 1: From out of the populous city men groan,  And the soul of the wounded crieth out:  Yet God regardeth not the folly.
Text 2: Out of the cities they have made men to groan, and the soul of the wounded hath cried out, and God doth not suffer it to pass unrevenged.

Text 1: The womb shall forget him; The worm shall feed sweetly on him; He shall be no more remembered; And unrighteousness shall be broken as a tree.
Text 2: The public place of his town has no more knowledge of him, and his name has gone from the memory of men: he is rooted up like a dead tree.

Text 1: They are exalted; yet a little while, and they are gone; Yea, they are brought low, they are taken out of the way as all       others, And are cut off as the tops of the ears of grain.
Text 2: For a short time they are lifted up; then they are gone; they are made low, they are pulled off like fruit, and like the heads of grain they are cut off.

Text 1: Why are times not laid up by the Almighty? And why do not they that know him see his days?
Text 2: Why are times not stored up by the Ruler of all, and why do those who have knowledge of him not see his days?

Text 1: The murderer riseth with the light; He killeth the poor and needy; And in the night he is as a thief.
Text 2: He who is purposing death gets up before day, so that he may put to death the poor and those in need.

Text 2: The murderer riseth with the light, killeth the afflicted and needy, and in the night is as a thief.

Text 2:
The murderer rises with the light.
He kills the poor and needy.
In the night he is like a thief.

Text 1: Yet [God] preserveth the mighty by his power: He riseth up that hath no assurance of life.
Text 2: But God by his power gives long life to the strong; he gets up again, though he has no hope of life.

Text 2: He draweth also the mighty with his power; he riseth up, and no [man] is sure of life.

Text 1: In the dark they dig through houses: They shut themselves up in the day-time; They know not the light.
Text 2: In the dark he makes holes in the walls of houses: in the daytime they are shutting themselves up, they have no knowledge of the light.

Text 2: In the dark they dig through houses; by day they shut themselves in; they know not the light:

Text 1: In the dark they dig through houses: They shut themselves up in the day-time; They know not the light.

which they had marked for themselves in the daytime: they know not the light.

Text 1: For the morning is to all of them as thick darkness; For they know the terrors of the thick darkness.
Text 2: For the middle of the night is as morning to them, they are not troubled by the fear of the dark.

Text 1: My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go: My heart shall not reproach [me] so long as I live.
Text 2: I will keep it safe, and will not let it go: my heart has nothing to say against any part of my life.

Text 2: My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go: my heart reproacheth [me] not one of my days.

Text 1: I will keep it safe, and will not let it go: my heart has nothing to say against any part of my life.
Text 2:
I hold fast to my righteousness, and will not let it go.
My heart will not reproach me so long as I live.

Text 1: My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go: my heart reproacheth [me] not one of my days.
Text 2: My justification, which I have begun to hold, I will not forsake: for my heart doth not reprehend me in all my life.

Text 1: Far be it from me that I should justify you: Till I die I will not put away mine integrity from me.
Text 2: Let it be far from me! I will certainly not say that you are right! I will come to death before I give up my righteousness.
